wikipedia_page.main: John Vincent Holland VC (19 July 1889 – 27 February 1975), was World War I Irish soldier, and the recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces.

response: *John Vincent Holland (1889–1975), British Army officer, and recipient of the Victoria Cross
* 27 February – John Vincent Holland, soldier, recipient of the Victoria Cross for gallantry in 1916 at Guillemont, France (born 1889).
* Lieutenant John Vincent Holland, 7th Leinsters, 16th (Irish) Division.
*19 July – John Vincent Holland, soldier, recipient of the Victoria Cross for gallantry in 1916 at Guillemont, France (died 1975).

The cemetery contains 124 Commonwealth war graves of service personnel, 49 from World War I and 75 from World War II; 40 of the graves are in a plot known as the Hobart War Cemetery, the remainder scattered throughout the cemetery. CWGC Cemetery record, Hobart (Cornelian Bay) Cemetery. The Commonwealth War Graves Commission also erected a memorial to 18 Australian service personnel - 16 soldiers, one sailor and one airman - who were cremated at the Crematorium in the latter war, CWGC Cemetery report, Hobart (Cornelian Bay) Crematorium. as well as the Tasmania Cremation Memorial, to four service personnel whose ashes were scattered elsewhere in Tasmania. John Vincent Holland, V.C., has his grave in the cemetery.  William Nevin Tatlow Hurst, Secretary for Lands (1925-1938) is buried in Section W, in his family's grave number 224.

79th (Hertfordshire Yeomanry) Heavy Anti-Aircraft Regiment, Royal Artillery
response: * Captain John Vincent Holland, Indian Army retired, who had won a Victoria Cross during World War I, was the administrative officer of the regiment when it was embodied in June 1939.Holland at Hellfire Corner.
